title: Beach
features: Bare sand and no vegetation.

title: Strandline
features: Lots of bare sand.
Annual plants present; may include sea rocket and prickly seawort.
Miniature sand dunes are formed around these plants.

title: Embryo Dune
features: Above the usual high tide line.
Lots of bare sand.
First perennial plants present; may include sand couch and lyme grass.
Low, hummocky dunes form around these plants.

title: Mobile Dune
features: Lots of bare sand (10-50%).
Marram grass dominates.
Sand builds up around marram to form high, mobile dunes.
A small number of other plants may be present; may include sea holly and sea spurge.

title: Semi-fixed Dune
features: Bare sand cover reduced.
Red fescue and mosses cover patches between marram.
Species diversity increasing; may include restharrow, sand sedge, birds foot trefoil.
No real soil layer.

title: Fixed Dune
features: Bare sand is only where turf is broken (less than 10%).
Soil beginning to form.
Many plants now coexisting; may include red fescue, ladyâ€™s bedstraw, harebell.
Surface lichens and mosses may be present.
Little if any scrub or tree cover.

title: Dune Slack
features: Flat, low-lying area.
Usually floods in winter.
Can be very large.
Species may include sedges, water mint, mosses and liverworts, creeping willow.

title: Heath
features: Soil is dry, acidic and nutrient-poor.
Plants present are those associated with acid grassland and heaths; may include heather.

title: Scrub and Woodland
features: Dominance of tall, woody perennials and understorey species.
Very little if any bare sand.
